Key Arguments: The legislation would severely restrict Australians' access to information, hindering their ability to make informed decisions.
Freedom of speech is a fundamental human right that the legislation would infringe upon.
The legislation would put Australia in breach of its international human rights obligations.
The government should not be the arbiter of truth, as it has previously provided misleading information, such as during the COVID-19 pandemic.
Main Themes: Freedom of speech and human rights
Access to information and critical thinking
Notable Quotes: I do not want my grandchildren to be spoon-fed a diet of 'this is what the government says, and you had better believe it.'

If the Communications Legislation Amendment (Combatting Misinformation and Disinformation) Bill 2023 were to pass, the Commonwealth of Australia would be in breach of its international human rights obligations.
Clearly governments cannot be trusted to speak the truth. It follows that they canâ€™t be trusted to decide what is true and what is false on behalf of the community.
